bibl.title: Vincent v. Boardman. Petition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: Judge of the Law Commissioners Court of S. Louis County:

The Petition of Elizabeth Vincent, alias Elizabeth Allen, respectfully that she is now held in active confinement & restraint of her liberty by Mr. Boardman, Jailor of S. Louis County, On a charge of being a fugitive from service or runaway slave: that she was born free, and has been free all her life; that she was arrested in the State of Illinois & brought over to this City and confined in Jail ever since: that she has been in said Jail about two weeks: that she has not applied for releif, nor been refused, by any court, officer superior to the one to whom this petition is presented; that she has applied for a copy of the papers accompanying or concerning her said confinment and the same has been refused. she therefore prays that your Honor will pass to her a writ of Habeas Corpus, to be denoted to the said commanding him to bring the body of the said Elizabeth Vincent, alias Allen, before you & require him to certify the cause of her detention:
Elizabeth Vincent, alias Elizabeth Allen, by Caude her attorney

Personally appeared Joseph Brooks who being
duly sworn in his oath says that he believes the facts state in the above petition to be true:
Subscribed & Sworn before me on this 13th day of May 1859
